captions.text: Air speed, 300. Go get him, mav.

Let's see if we can scare
this guy out of here.

( <i>targeting system toning</i> )
I got him locked. Bingo.
He's bugging out and going home.

A hundred and eighty miles
at bearing 0-1-0, sir.

Cougar, he's got missile lock
on us. Get away from this guy.

What the hell is this shit?
He's engaging me.

Goddamn it, mustang.
This is ghost rider,
Do I have permission to fire?
Do not fire until fired upon.

Goose, there they are,
right below us.

Goose:
The mig's in perfect firing
position.
He's just trying to piss us off.

Maverick, get down here
and get this asshole off me.
Help me engage. I'm on my way.

I can't shoot
this son of a bitch.

Let's see if we can have
a little fun with him.
Is this your idea of fun, mav?
This is a great shot, mav.

<i>Your tail is clear.</i>
<i>Mig one's bugged out.</i>

comments.author: Joshua Parrott

comments.text:
It's funny how people don't realize that for most of the movie, the Russian 
MiGs and American F-14's were not directly hostile to each other. The plot 
is set during the Cold War, when there were heavy military and political 
tensions between the U.S. and Russia but no full declaration of war was 
ever made. 

The events of the movie itself are fictional, but the reason that 
intimidation and fear tactics - such as missile locks and Maverick's stunt 
here - is because both sides were working on a RoE that specified that they 
weren't to fire unless fired upon. The entirety of the Cold War was like 
this - a lot of threats with very little actual combat.

The final dogfight has Russian MiGs engaging U.S. aircraft first because, 
as the CAG reports, a disabled U.S. ship drifted into Russian territory and 
the MiGs were sent to intercept it on the assumption that it was a warship 
exhibiting hostile intent and breaking the ceasefire. ﻿

comments.text:
Trivia: (from imdb.com) The pilot that gets "flipped off" by Maverick and 
Goose is Admiral Robert Willard, the lead flight choreographer for the 
film. He was Commander of the United States Pacific Fleet (2007-2009) 
before transferring to United States Pacific Command.
